course.subject: ENVR
course.name: The Smart Consumer - Uncovering the Hidden Story behind the Product Label
course.description: The choices we make in daily life - the food we eat, the clothes we wear, the products and services we use - define our lifestyle. With increasing pressure through climate change and resource constraints, many people intend to consume in a sustainable manner. But with vague “green promises,” complex ingredient lists, and opaque production processes, we often do not know what is inside the products we use and how they were made. This course will investigate everyday products and explore features that make them (un)sustainable by applying a product life-cycle approach. It will also provide insights into the factors that influence our consumption decisions and how consumer behavior can be changed. Students get the opportunity (through small exercises, activities, and discussions) to investigate about consumption in Hong Kong and explore how companies and governments can help individual consumers to make smarter, more sustainable consumption choices.

reviews.author: hkhkhk
reviews.title: Very helpful and interesting course
reviews.comment_content: The content is mostly about sustainability and how we, as consumers, can assess the life cycle of products. The lectures also look into the ethics and business part of sustainability, so it's helpful for students from all majors. Since sustainability is a new field of study compared to math or science, the content was very interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: Meike always put effort in communicating with students to help their understanding. She made use a lot of zoom polls in make the lecture interactive. By referring to real life examples the concepts were easy to understand and actually really interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair. You get what you put in. Meike is really looks deeply in all your assignments and grades with a fair standard. For you to get a A, you have to put quite a lot of effort and your contents should actually be good.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is fair. Considering there are no midterms and finals, there are a lot of assignments. The assignments were mostly answering to review questions on a word document. However, there is also a lot of group work. Getting good group mates is crucial for this course.

reviews.comment_workload:
There were 2 homework (there were actually 3 but the last one was optional so I didn't pay attention). The homework were in different formats: hw1 was production of a video introducing the consumption pattern in Hong Kong context, of course each group have different focus/topic; hw2 was a case study on a German supermarket, and we gotta think of some pros and cons of their marketing scheme when applied in a supermarket in HK.

There were 3 chapter review: basically we gotta respond to questions, within a word limit, which requires our thorough understanding in the key concepts in the chapter.

Finally the group project: required us to look into a topic, again, differed from groups to groups, so we dissected the consumption pattern and gave a suggested solution.

reviews.author: kwagor
reviews.title: Interesting content but a heavy workload and not easy to have good grade.
reviews.comment_content:
A very informative content, address the concept and the determination of sustainability with a broad range of cases or examples to be analyzed weekly.
E.g. Life-cycle Assessment, Environmental impact of a product throughout its supply chain. Child-labor, Social impact.

Factors to affect consumer behaviors and lifestyle patterns are also discussed in the class, also the relationship of them to sustainability issues.
E.g. Minimalism, Materialism, Over-consuming due to promotion aids (discount, rewards).

Ways to push people toward a sustainable lifestyle, in terms of Corporate perspective/ Governmental Policies/ Marketing Strategies/ Social Education.

Although it seems to be quite related to Chemistry, in fact, it isn't.
There is only a tiny amount of chemical substances be mentioned  in the last module of the course, in related to sustainability concerns, like additives in food, cosmetics, and textile.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very interesting, you would never fall asleep or distracted during her class, while she explains the concepts very clearly and presents them logically.

She prepares her slides pretty well, there is no rush of the ppts, especially as this is her first time teaching in zoom.

Forget about the TAs, they are not fluent English speakers, and they seemed not very prepared for help. Save your time to ask Meike, she response email very fast.

reviews.comment_workload:
Very demanding, the deadlines are so cramped, after the first week of add/drop period, HW1 has to be due. Also, the course materials only cover a general understanding of the concepts, for the HWs, they required you more specific understandings, you have to do research = more time spent on reading or searching for materials.

Almost every lect would involve group discussion, and there is a worksheet to be filled in and hand-in at the end of lects.

Requires a good skill of media editing (filming, audio-edit, PS, animation for short Video), word/ppt formatting, creative media creation (poster, social media posts).

Although there is no Final Exam/Midterms/Quizzes, all of these assignments are very time-consuming. Also, >50% are related to Group work, which implies the possibility of facing sb's procrastination.

Participation (9%)

A mark or two can differ by a subgrade, but this is average HKUST.

Overall, the grade is normally distributed.

One drawback is that she grades the assignments really slow but with detailed feedback. She explains that this is the reason why she graded extremely slow. This semester, she released part of the grading in the middle of the semester which was a bit useful in knowing she standards and how she grades us.

There are many grading components so please refer to the attached document.

Overall, the grading is nice. I got an overall B with all my review questions touching mean, and group projects are way above mean.

The key to have a good grade is to have great groupmates as group projects are the main components in this course. I would suggest that you enroll in this course with your friends to prevent any unhappy events.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is okay...until Meike could not finish setting up the questions on time and postpone everything till week 13.

The review questions didn't require a long time in working on it (I spend one afternoon finishing it). But the group project does, with the last review questions and last group project all crash into week 13 and given that I need to prepare for 2 exams. the workload is very high at this period.
Just be prepared when you see Meike is off schedule and this is what will happen -- having tons of deadlines towards the end of semester.

But Meike is nice, and is willing to postpone deadlines if we requested.

3 Chapter reviews: 10% each
Group project report: 25%
Peer evaluation: 5%
Participation: 10%

Final score: 84%
Final grade: B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Participation: she counts input in zoom chat box, so if you don't like to speak in class, you can just type in the chat box.

Chapter review: three submissions in total, she will post a list of questions, you just need to answer them based on course material and some personal experience. She gives reaaaaally detailed feedback to them so you know how to improve on the next one.

Homework: those are group homework that the first one needs you to produce one 3-min short video. You can do animations, drama, or just a ppt presentation. The second one is a case presentation, where you have to read a case, and she gives you a guideline to prepare two sets of presentation. She will tell you which set she would like when you present. She cancelled homework 3, instead she added one more questions to both chapter review 2 and 3.

Group project: finish a project, read more from the syllabus.

Workload is not heavy, only if you have responsible groupmates. Groupmates are very important, I repeat, VERY IMPORTANT. It would be the best if you have friends studying the course with you, so you won't need to deal with groupmates who just don't care about the course and your work.

reviews.author: deetee
reviews.comment_content:
As a business student, I learnt quite a bit from this course. It was very enriching and it opened my eyes. It taught me about so many things that I can apply in many different practical situations.
Overview:
Consumer trends, business trends, policies
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Meike is nothing short of brilliant when it comes to teaching. She keeps the class engaged at all times through many interesting activities and games. Would highly recommend this Prof for a lot of classes!
She gives excellent feedback and is very approachable, friendly and just a pleasant person to even be around! Stick around after class for a quick chat with her and ask her all your doubts. She is very passionate about the subject and teaches with a lot of interest and puts in waaaaay more effort than most other profs at UST lolll
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading. (UST profs who teach well don't always grade the best... But that's a trade-off we all have to make at some point).
Got above mean in everything by putting in a GOOOOD amount of effort. Still waiting for the final grade, but I do expect an A-range grade.
Definitely one of those classes where you have to put in a lot of effort for a good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty good workload, but that's because I was only doing one course for the summer. It might be difficult if you are doing it in the Fall or Spring, so think twice if you are going to laze around. Don't become a free-rider, please!
Only take up this course if you are willing to put in the effort because you are learning something new out of it.

reviews.author: cllw26
reviews.comment_content:
mainly about sustainability e.g.product life cycle, materialism
need no knowledge about chemistry
content is somehow rich and deep
do not choose if you are totally not interested in sustainability stuff
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good teaching, clear concept, comfortable English, quite nice, tries hard to teach well, i feel her passion
but too early lecture for me, often fall asleep
she will change the assignment deadline if u ask for
give long long reading materials sometimes, one or two days before lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
i am not good at writing essay + not very active in participating in class(raise hand ask/answer questions or chatroom discussion), so poor grade
good teammates help a lot a lot
reviews.comment_workload:
task after task, essay after essay, grp project after grp project
don't choose the course only because it has no final exam
always have group discussions(breakout room) almost every lecture, and TA/Prof will visit your room (give part of the participation mark according to this)
need to submit a short ppt slide or word doc. after each group discussion
u may want to type your fruitful ideas in chatroom to gain participation marks
project content include making videosss and doing research on companies
one of the most demanding courses i have taken

reviews.author: Studdas
reviews.title: Course Review for 1080
reviews.comment_content:
This class aims to analyze what motivates people when making purchasing decisions and how can smart, sustainable consumption be promoted. At the same time, the class provides insides on what makes specific products and consumer behaviour unsustainable and what are the consequences of current consumption patterns on the environment and our society.
There are games and innovative surveys to help you understand these things.
reviews.comment_teaching:
1. She explains concepts well.
2. TA does not do much so do not expect any help from her.
3. Meike, herself is very helpful and is always ready to help you with your projects or essays.
4. Results of the Homeworks are given late so you are not exactly sure as to what you have to improve in your next set of homework.
reviews.comment_grading:
I was disappointed with the grading for this course to be honest.
Video or Essay - 20%
Group-Project (Presentation) or Report - 40%
Homework - 30%
Throughout the semester participation - 10%
Attendance is important. You can miss a maximum of 2 classes.
I got above mean in my group project, marginally below mean in my homework and ended up with a B+
reviews.comment_workload:
No midterm and a final exam which is good but there is a decent amount of workload.
Group Project - The workload for this course is a bit much. But it depends on how you divide your time among other courses. My group of 5 was extremely unproductive apart from 2 of us who single-handedly completed the entire group project in 3 days. So, be careful while choosing a group.
Video or Essay - Three topics are given by the professor and you can either make a video or submit an essay. The workload for this is not that much.
Homework - The homework involves writing an essay, going to fusion and reviewing products etc.
It is manageable

reviews.author: masterchef
reviews.comment_content: Quite interesting if you are into environmental topics. Like you may understand how different stakeholders in society can contribute such as partners in the supply chain and the government. Also, you may have a better understanding of sustainability issues like the definition of "sustainable products".
reviews.comment_teaching: She is quite passionate about the topics and she prepares the course materials quite well. I think she values interaction with students so she will ask quite a lot of questions for students to contribute to the lesson.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading. Mark for the group project is slightly higher than mean. Assignments are basically graded slightly above the mean.

Attendance will be graded upon contribution to lessons and questionnaires conducted during lessons. I did attend 80% so probably didn't miss any questionnaires. Or actually, you may ask your groupmates or friends to help you out. I got a B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Have to complete an essay regarding topics covered in the lecture twice a week (400-1,000 words). There's a group project as well but it's not difficult to finish. You may choose to have a presentation or write a report/brochure.

No mid-term and final.

reviews.author: wanji
reviews.comment_content:
Common Sense Content with some interesting facts that you might not know before
Understandable and worth listening and reflecting
reviews.comment_teaching: She is an enthusiastic professor to promote sustainability. She tried to organize more inclass discussions and activities to keep us engaged in the lessons. She also managed to hold a game learning session for us which was fun! She did expect students to answer her questions and participate in her class. So far, she is one of the best professors in HKUST i 've ever seen
reviews.comment_grading: Good grade in terms of the workload and participation.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload. Only 2 assignments in the term plus few homework (~400 word essay or research activity) Easy to be done and well she gave detailed feedback for every homework you submitted.

reviews.author: snoopy1212
reviews.title: Good course for satisfying CC requirements
reviews.comment_content: Realistically, some parts are quite interesting. Others, not so much. Quite straight forward content that anyone with enough common sense would already know.
reviews.comment_teaching: Meike does spend a lot of time preparing for her lessons and answering our questions. She's a good teacher but it's just unlucky that this class is usually filled with people who really don't give a f*** about anything. Be warned that she expects everybody to contribute at least once a class or you're not gonna get a good attendance grade.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. I could even say that the homework part gives you some excellent grading. I got 25/30 for hwk but got ripped by my group getting only a 30/40 for the final project. Ended up with a B+ for final. Note: No midterms or finals so spend some time on your work before handing in. I rambled for most of my parts and still got good grades so no stress really.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite good IMO. Just do your stuff early and don't leave it till the end. She gives you plenty of time to complete the work. Plus, there's no need to do every single piece of assignment as she only expects you to hand in sth like 5 out of 9 pieces to be able to get full marks (providing your hwk is good ofc).

reviews.author: chcx
reviews.comment_content:
The content is actually related to daily lives so it is not hard to understand. It also provides insights about environmental issues and social aspects behind products.
Part1- Understanding consumer behavior
Part2- Why are products unsustainable
Part3- Motivating sustainable consumption
Part4- Product Close up
reviews.comment_teaching: Meike is one of the best professors in the UST. She is very very nice and encouraging. She also put a lot of in-class activities to make the learning atmosphere more relax and effective. I think she really raises the consciousness of students to be more eco-friendly and "be the smart consumers". She provided many insights and aspects that I did not think of.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite good
did not actively participate in lessons, got 19.5/20 in the essay, overall got 84% and turns out B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not big at all, only the group project would take some time. Other than that, homework is quite easy and based on lecture materials.

20% Video or Essay
40% Group project (presentation or brochure)
30% Homework (7 assignments, not necessarily to finish all, only those with 4 highest marks among all assignments you finished will be counted)
10% Participation

reviews.author: uststudent
reviews.title: Good Course , interesting topic
reviews.comment_content: Lots of ingredients in the product labels are just chemical form which is not easy to know whether they are good or not. This course teaches you methods to choose a good product that is sustainable. Quite useful in our daily life.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is very nice and encouraging. She always ask questions and holds interaction discussion about various products. There was a potato chips testing session which you could eat a lot of chips.
reviews.comment_grading: Do all the assignments and answer questions during class. B+ at last. You may need a good teammate to carry you for a better grading as there is a final project in the end.
reviews.comment_workload: not high, no quiz or exam, quite relaxing. The assignment is not hard to do, but the mean is quite high.

reviews.author: Luke King
reviews.title: good project mates help you a lot
reviews.comment_content: You can learn a wide range of topics from this course, from how to consume smarter to how does the insecticide used in agriculture harms the environment. HOWEVER, I think some of them are just common sense, and you don't really need them to finish your assignment. But she teaches more than the ppt so I don't think you can skip all the classes and read the ppt only.
reviews.comment_teaching: quite boring, especially when you know there is no midterm and final. Many people skip classes when there is no class activity. At least her way to teach won't make you fall asleep coz she won't read the ppt only.
reviews.comment_grading: There are mainly 2 parts, class activity and assignment. She will upload the class activity's timetable at the beginning of the semester, so you know when can you skip the class. There are 3 assignments, 1 individual report and 2 group assignment (video making and report/presentation). Choosing good group mates is really important. If i really right, less than 7 people can get an A (or A range)
reviews.comment_workload: no midterm no final so you don't need to memorize anything. but the video making might take you some times. and she usually extends the deadlines.

reviews.author: Peipar
reviews.title: Fun Class
reviews.comment_content:
1. (Un)Sustainable Consumption

2. (Un)Sustainable Products

3. Sustainable Consumption in Hong Kong

4. Challenges and Barriers for Sustainable Consumption

5. How To Recognize 'Sustainable Products': Eco-Labels and Greenwashing

6. Product Sustainability: Ethical Considerations and Textile

7. Product Sustainability: Food

8. Enabling Sustainable Consumption: Corporate Action

9. Why Do We Consume So Much

10. Consumption and Happiness, and Changing Consumption Behavior

11. Enabling Sustainable Consumption: Governmental Actions

12. Work, Consumption and Happiness: The LOOP Game

I think the content is very appropriate and useful as an introduction to sustainability.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very good.

Her lectures are quite fun and interactive, 3-hour lectures felt like 1 hour casual discussions, quite relaxing and easy to follow.

Meike is very knowledgeable about this topic, so you can ask her whatever you want.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Quizzes (Best 6/9 graded)
20% Presentation or Report (2nd groupwork)
15% Report (1st groupwork)
10% Sustainability Challenge 1 (individual)
10% Sustainability Challenge 2 (individual)
10% Participation & Attendance
5% Peer Evaluation

Grading is fair, not difficult to get B-range but not easy to get A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not bad.

There are many in-class activities during lectures, both individual and group.

Quiz is basically every or every-other lecture, as long as you attend the lecture, you should be able to do most of the questions, no need to spend hours studying or memorizing anything, maybe just review the lecture slides few minutes before the quiz, or even during the quiz as they are open-book.

Sustainability challenges are tedious, but understandable.

The two groupworks are the most time-consuming, but it's not too bad as long as your group doesn't have any free-riders.

reviews.author: Smart
reviews.comment_content: You will love this course if you want to know how sustainable consumption is. Almost the whole course is about sustainable consumption, like the eco-label, the concept of greenwashing. I would say this is quite useful if you concern about the label on the product. You can figure out which label is fake and which is real.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is fine I think. Quite fun in the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
No midterm and final exams.
There are 9 quizzes. 6 of them will be counted. Total 30%.
Two group works 35%.
Two sustainability challenges 20%
Attendance 10%
Peer evaluation 5%
reviews.comment_workload: There are around 5-6 homework. I think it is a fair workload. Homework is not difficult to do.

reviews.author: Hayoha
reviews.title: Good professor
reviews.comment_content:
Sustainable consumption
Sustainable products
Consumption and Happiness
LOOP Game
Why do we consume so much?
Sustainable consumption in Hong Kong
Challenges and barriers for sustainable consumption
How to recognize sustainable products?
Changing consumer behavior
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Meike is very nice and patient. Her Lecture notes are well-prepared and easy to read. She has good management for Lectures.
She played videos during lectures and they really help preventing me to fall asleep. There is 1 break for each Lecture since it lasts for nearly 3 hours. She is willing to answer questions and reply emails.
reviews.comment_grading:
Have 5 quizzes (count for the best 3) 15%
originally have 4 quizzes only.
2 group projects (including presentation) 15% each

1 guided essay 10%
2 review questions-Take-home exam 15% each (i think they like LS paper 1)

Participation 10%
Peer evaluation 5%

I got the LOWEST mark for both of my 2 group projects.
But i got my quizzes, and other assignments above/ equal to the mean. Total about 86.22% and i got A-. I think the grading is good.
From my memory: the professor said she could only give about 20% students with A range and about 40%(this number i am not very sure) B range.
reviews.comment_workload:
It is very depend. I only reg for this course for summer. I think the topics are not difficult. For each quiz, you need to spend for 1-2 hours to do the revision. Then for essay and review questions, i took about 6-8 hours for each of them. If you are taking several courses or have other activities during summer, this course may not suitable for you. For participation, i mostly answered questions in zoom chat box. The professor accepted this kind of participating  .But i joined all the real-time classes at school. There are a few (4-5) students are super active on classes. I guess they should get full mark. I got about 9 among 10.

The group projects are important. You can choose your group mates in case you are studying with you friends. If meet freeriders..... then you may need to finish the whole project yourself.
